channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Wear Your Mask. Please. No, Not on Your Chin.
item.description: More than 30 states have enacted mask requirements to guard against the coronavirus. But local authorities have had a difficult time enforcing them.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Mark Hedden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bill Michael, a resident of Key West, Fla., voiced his frustration with the city’s mask ordinance to Officer Nick Dantu this month.

item.title: Undocumented Housekeeper Who Worked at Trump Property Could Face Deportation
item.description: Victorina Morales was one of many undocumented workers at Trump Organization golf properties who came forward. She was placed in removal proceedings this week. A judge will decide on her bid for asylum.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Christopher Gregory for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victorina Morales sometimes cleaned Donald Trump’s personal quarters at the Bedminster, N.J., golf resort.

item.title: Native Americans Fight Coronavirus and Deficient Data
item.description: Statistical gaps can make it difficult to properly allocate public resources to Native Americans. When that’s the case, one leader said, “tribal nations have an effective death sentence.”
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Robert Gebeloff and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers assembling care packages and food at the Wapato Community Center in Wapato, Wash., this month.

item.title: John Lewis Funeral: ‘A Man of Pure Joy and Unbreakable Perseverance’
item.description: The civil rights leader was eulogized by former presidents and family in Atlanta, the city he represented in Congress for more than three decades.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Melissa Golden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners outside Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta watched as former President Barack Obama spoke at John Lewis’s funeral on Thursday.

item.title: Court Frees Michigan Teen Who Was Held for Skipping Online Schoolwork
item.description: The release came more than a week after a judge ruled that the girl, who violated the terms of her probation by skipping coursework, should remain at the juvenile facility.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: People protested in support of the high school student outside Oakland County Circuit Court in Pontiac, Mich., earlier this month.

item.title: A Better Year for Trump’s Family Business (Last Year, That Is)
item.description: In 2019, the Trump Organization showed improvement over the previous year. But the company’s minimum reported revenues still fell short of the president’s first year in office, his new financial disclosure shows.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, Steve Eder and Michael H. Keller
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mar-a-Lago, in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: As Unemployment Aid Expires, White House and Congress Clash on Relief Plan
item.description: President Trump and Democrats blamed each other for the lapse of $600-per-week federal unemployment benefits, risking further economic pain and a voter backlash for failing to act.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, blamed Democrats on Friday for the expiration of the unemployment benefits, saying they rejected multiple proposals to temporarily extend them.

item.title: Trump’s Coronavirus Testing Chief Concedes a Lag in Test Results
item.description: With the reopening plans of schools and businesses hinging on rapid test results, the Trump administration’s testing czar says a two- to three-day turnaround “is not possible.”
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a lengthy House hearing on Friday, Adm. Brett P. Giroir told lawmakers that the nation was now averaging about 820,000 tests daily, up from 550,000 earlier this month.

item.title: The Coronavirus Infected Hundreds at a Georgia Summer Camp
item.description: The camp took precautions but did not require campers to wear masks, the C.D.C. reported. Singing and cheering may have helped spread the virus.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Supreme Court Lets Trump Keep Building His Border Wall
item.description: The court refused to lift a year-old stay notwithstanding an appeals court ruling that the construction was unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument in Arizona, where part of President Trump’s border wall is being built.

item.title: Alaska Midair Collision Kills 7, Officials Say
item.description: Gary Knopp, a Republican member of the State House of Representatives, was among those killed. He was piloting one of the planes.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:description: Gary Knopp was elected an Alaska state representative in 2016. He was killed in a midair crash near Soldotna, Alaska, on Friday morning, officials said.

item.title: Trump Campaign Halts TV Ads as He Struggles in Polls Against Biden
item.description: The six-day pause was ordered by the president’s new campaign manager, Bill Stepien.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti, Annie Karni and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump will be launching “a new ad campaign” on Monday.

item.title: Trump Officials Reconsider Prosecuting ISIS ‘Beatles’ Without Death Penalty
item.description: American military officials in Iraq want two detainees taken off their hands and a British court has blocked sharing evidence for any death-penalty case. But other options are also getting a second look.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Alexanda Kotey, left, and El Shafee Elsheikh are Britons who made up half of a brutal Islamic State cell called the “Beatles.”

item.title: Mail Delays Fuel Concern Trump Is Undercutting Postal System Ahead of Voting
item.description: The president’s long campaign against the Postal Service is intersecting with his assault on mail-in voting amid concerns that he has politicized oversight of the agency.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Hailey Fuchs and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:description: The Postal Service, which runs more than 31,000 post offices in the United States, has struggled financially for years, in part because of its legal obligation to deliver mail everywhere.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: New estimates gauge the risk of returning to classrooms.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Despite Historic Plunge, Europe’s Economy Flashes Signs of Recovery
item.description: European countries that have better contained the virus are poised for speedier economic recovery than the United States.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman, Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

item.title: Motorist Who Shot a Protester in Austin Claims Self-Defense
item.description: A ride-share driver fatally shot an armed demonstrator, Garrett Foster, over the weekend. The police are still trying to sort out what happened.
item.dc:creator: David Montgomery and Manny Fernandez
item.media:description: Signs and flowers lined a bench at a vigil for Garrett Foster last weekend in downtown Austin, Texas. Mr. Foster was shot and killed after a chaotic altercation with a motorist who drove into the crowd.

item.title: Homeland Security Shuts Down ‘Intelligence’ Reports on Journalists
item.description: The acting secretary of homeland security said that he would investigate his department’s dissemination of the tweets of journalists who uncovered agency documents.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Chad Wolf, the acting secretary of homeland security, last week at the White House. He said on Friday that he had ordered the intelligence arm to discontinue collecting information involving journalists.

item.title: The Unschooled Artists
item.description: Taking lessons in creativity from my kids.
item.dc:creator: Austin Kleon

item.title: Boston Marathon Bomber’s Death Sentence Is Thrown Out by Court
item.description: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted after bombings that killed three people and wounded more than 260, will receive a new penalty-phase trial.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to the victims of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, which killed three people and injured more than 260 others.

item.title: Countering G.O.P. on Courts, Democrats Will Call for ‘Structural’ Change
item.description: Progressives pushed for the platform language after President Trump’s drive put 200 conservative judges on the federal bench and Senate Republicans blocked President Obama’s nominees.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joe Biden’s campaign has signaled that they are open to structural changes to the courts.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Roland Johnson, Who Fought to Shut Down Institutions for the Disabled
item.description: He survived 13 years of neglect and abuse, including sexual assault, at the notorious Pennhurst State School and Hospital outside Philadelphia before emerging as a champion for the disabled.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Rifkin

item.title: Microsoft Said to Be in Talks to Buy TikTok, as Trump Weighs Curtailing App
item.description: The discussions come as TikTok’s ownership by a Chinese company is under scrutiny by the White House and lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac, Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:description: Trump administration officials have been concerned that TikTok poses a threat to national security.

item.title: Trump Still Defers to Putin, Even as He Dismisses U.S. Intelligence and the Allies
item.description: Say this about President Trump’s approach to Moscow: It’s been consistent.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Trump has repeatedly said he did not trust his own intelligence agencies’ assessments of Russian activities.

item.title: U.S. Adds Sanctions Over Internment of Muslims in China
item.description: The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on a powerful government entity that runs companies and farms in the Xinjiang region, where officials carry out the mass internment of Muslims.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and the White House chief of staff, Mark Meadows, on Capitol Hill Thursday. The impact of the sanctions on a powerful government group was not clear.

item.title: Hurricane Isaias Rakes the Bahamas on a Track for Florida’s East Coast
item.description: The National Hurricane Center issued a hurricane warning for over 150 miles of the Florida coastline, stretching from Boca Raton to the northern bound of Brevard County.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Residents of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic cleaned up their homes after Hurricane Isaias moved through on Friday.

item.title: Karen Bass, Susan Rice Rise As Biden's Search for V.P. Nears End
item.description: Two women, Representative Karen Bass and Susan Rice, the former national security adviser, are among the most formidable contenders on Joe Biden’s list.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is said to be focused chiefly on finding a running mate whom he regards as capable of advancing his priorities in government.

item.title: In 1920, Native Women Sought the Vote. Here’s What They Seek Now.
item.description: The 19th Amendment did not bring the right to vote to all Native women, but two experts in a conversation said it did usher in the possibility of change.
item.dc:creator: Cathleen D. Cahill and Sarah Deer

item.title: Covid-19 Testing Is in Short Supply. Should You Still Get a Test?
item.description: Public health officials once suggested only people with symptoms should be tested. Now some say getting one is a civic duty.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family at a testing site in Miami Springs, Fla. Getting a coronavirus test, like wearing a mask, shows “a desire to be a part of the solution,” an epidemiologist said.

item.title: Are Massage Therapists Considered Essential Workers?
item.description: Some counties in California have not allowed personal care businesses to reopen. Other counties have moved them exclusively outdoors.
item.dc:creator: Marie Tae McDermott
item.media:description: In mid-July, Gov. Gavin Newsom gave guidelines for barber shops, nail salons and massage businesses that allowed them to stay in practice, if they moved outdoors.

item.title: 1 Marine Dead and 8 Others Are Missing After California Amphibious Vehicle Accident
item.description: The group was assigned to a unit based at Camp Pendleton in Southern California, and the episode involved an amphibious assault vehicle, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Marie Fazio
item.media:description: Camp Pendleton, in Southern California, hosts the largest Marine base on the West Coast.

item.title: Kamala Harris Pushes Back on Criticism of ‘Ambition’
item.description: President Trump warned of an “election disaster” with mail-in voting, but cited no evidence of fraud. Joe Biden has postponed his planned announcement of a running mate.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris on Capitol Hill on Tuesday. Joseph R. Biden Jr. is considering her as his running mate.

item.title: Voting by Mail Is Popular. So Is the False Idea That It’s Ripe for Fraud.
item.description: Americans overwhelmingly support increased access to mail voting, but they also appear to be susceptible to misinformation about it.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: One political risk for President Trump is that his effort to portray mail voting as unreliable will drive down Republican participation, giving an advantage to Democrats.

item.title: Outdoors Innovation
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Coronavirus Live News: World Updates
item.description: California became the first state to reach 500,000 total cases. Once the site of a major outbreak, Italy now offers lessons for keeping the virus in check.

item.title: Contact Tracing Is Failing in Many States. Here’s Why.
item.description: Inadequate testing and protracted delays in producing results have crippled tracking and hampered efforts to contain major outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer and Abby Goodnough
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: Contact tracing in an office at the Florida Department of Health in Miami-Dade County in May.

item.title: Trump's Election Delay Tweet Undercuts Democracy
item.description: Floating the idea of delaying the election was the latest step in the president’s running effort to discredit the election, risking long-term damage to public trust in the system.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump floated the idea of delaying the election in a tweet on Thursday, risking the erosion of the most important ingredient in a democracy — the belief by most Americans that the election results will be fundamentally fair.

item.title: Lizard Popsicles, Anyone?
item.description: The coolest reptiles on the planet occasionally freeze solid.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Rapp Learn
item.media:description: A very cold female Liolaemus quilmes lizard in an experiment at California State University, Northridge.
